"We would like the working party to think more radically about non-resuscitation, withdrawal of treatment decisions, the best interests test and active euthanasia as they are ways of widening the management options available to the sickest of newborns."
 
 The headlines focus on active euthanasia, but I think that non-resuscitation and withdrawal of treatment are not black and white, and certainly worthy of debate.
 
 Has anyone heard of Baby K? It is an interesting and relevant case.
 
 http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/464018_4
 
 Deciding whether to artificially sustain the life of a newborn with a condition that would normally result in death within a couple weeks has nothing to do with whether they "want" the baby IMO.

mercy and killing should never be put together.
 
 there is no such thing as having so much compassion that justifies you putting a toddler to death. Dont people realize that children are gifts and not something that should be taken so lightly as to steep so low in stopping a beating heart all for the sake of selfishness and convenience for one's self.. There is absolutely no thought whatsoever in the baby, its all about "how can i live easier without this problem?".
 
 there is no such thing as compassionate killing. What it really means is "killing in the name of mercy for my comfort".
 
 people need to start realizing that the world doesnt revolve around them and that life itself is a gift TO ALL! EVEN THOSE LITTLE ONES THAT PEOPLE RIGHT NOW THINK DONT HAVE ANY RIGHT TO LIVE. look in the mirror!

 My life was a gift from my parents, no more, no less. When i look in the mirror, i do not see an embryo. If someone gives you something, they have every right to take it away if they feel you are not suited to handle it, or if they had second thoughts. I would think this was ok if the baby was stopped in an earlier stage, but once its in its third trimester, you have no right to kill it.

That is completely inaccurate.
 There is a great deal of objective evidence to support the existence of a big bang of some sort.
 It has nothing to do with faith.
 
 Please tell me why you think it is a "faith statement?"

 
 You have put your faith in a theory that has been inferred by other people who have huge biases, who gathered a bunch of random data and tried to create specific meaning out of it that was geared toward a certain bias. They came up with a cool story and you believed it when someone told you it. "Billions of years" stand between you and these events and no one was "there" much less you yourself. Did you collect the data? I don't think so. Have you seen every piece of "evidence"? Nope - a clear element of blind belief at the personal level. Faith is clearly involved here. 
 
 Moose, seriously, stop and think for a minute: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FfPepiBxK_M&mode=related&search=
 
 We are not random warts in a meaningless universe. We are not simply the sum of a bunch of parts. I think the fact you acknowledge any element of "personhood" at all is very interesting. What do you base it on? You would be right to think that human life has inherent value and meaning. "Inherent" - This means that value and meaning do not depend on whether people acknowledge or believe in it or not - it exists. It doesn't matter how many people say the human fetus does not have value or meaning - the human fetus has value and meaning. This dignity comes from outside of the human experience - bestowed by the Creator. This is why the issue of abortion is such a serious matter. It is not only an attack on the most innocent and powerless of our species, it is an attack on the inherent dignity and worth of the human race.

You have put your faith in a theory that has been inferred by other people who have huge biases, who gathered a bunch of random data and tried to create specific meaning out of it that was geared toward a certain bias. They came up with a cool story and you believed it when someone told you it. "Billions of years" stand between you and these events and no one was "there" much less you yourself. Did you collect the data? I don't think so. Have you seen every piece of "evidence"? Nope - a clear element of blind belief at the personal level. Faith is clearly involved here. 

 
 There is no faith.
 There is no huge bias.
 The data are not random.
 It is not a story.
 There is no blind belief.
 
 You have no idea what you are talking about.
 Why are you so upset?
 Have I touched a nerve?

 Initially, it was met with criticism.
 But, as corroborating evidence acccumulated, more scientists began to accept this.
 It is nothing at all like what you describe.
 
 You seem like an innocent.
 A babe in the wood.
 Grow.
 Listen.
 Learn.
 Life is so much grander and beautiful than the limitations you impose on it.

 Meaning and values and beauty and morals all can exist outside the stringent limitations you impose on it with your silly, supersitious beliefs. These things are so much greater and awesome and humbling if you don't constrain them with your mythology. 
 
 You are missing so much.
 Go to a real school - leave the home school.

 Funny thing is, I know Christian scientists, who believe in the big bang, who say that their religion adds so much meaning and excellence to their scientific work. It seems not everyone shares your worldview that religion only constricts science.

There is no faith.
 There is no huge bias.
 The data are not random.
 It is not a story.
 There is no blind belief.

 
 There is a big bias - That God is not there.
 
 The data is random as far as science is concerned - science cannot make sense of these facts, that is up to the fallible and biased peeps to do.
 
 
 
 I do not deny that the scientific method produces real facts. The truth is that there is only one correct interpretation of these facts. There is only one truth. You, along with a majority of the scientific community have placed your faith in certain interpretations. While it is true that even a blind squirrel can find a nut once in a while, it can hardly be factually concluded that the blind squirrels have found the nut on this particular theory. It just so happens that this theory along with the THEORY of macroevolution provides the foundational basis for our "science". Faith in this "science" then provides the basis for existing in this life and is extrapolated to allow one to "factually say" that the embryo is not a person. That is so ridiculous and sad.
 
 While science may produce some facts that are repeatable, there is no way that science can always give us the correct meaning of these facts. The scientific method ends where interpretation of these facts begin. Fallible folk, through cloudy biased lenses, create biased interpretation of facts in which people put their faith. Ahh, the "scientific" hermeneutic. It is this biased hermeneutic that leads the scientific community to conclude that when it find two extra fins on a dolphin it is "evidence" that dolphins once walked. Please, that is rediculous. How can you be sure the interpretation of these facts is correct? They take these interpretations as authority which becomes the foundation for more interpreting, instituting more bias. People then take these theories of others blindly (enter some faith here) and build their lives upon them. Faith in these theories becomes the basis for their belief about things like morality and justice and personhood.
 
 One practical example for this discussion is the fetus. People receive the evidence that a fetus might not be viable at a certain point, or that the fetus cannot think. Ok, so what. Ok, now from this evidence they conclude that the fetus is not a person. This is faith in action.

Chloe, you are being quite insulting in your portrayal of thousands of years worth of scientific work and research. These astronomers, physicists, methematicians, biologists, and palentologists did not just toss a few ideas together. They most certianly were not blind. And any of them could easily nail you, or I, to the wall in battle of the wits. 
 
 When you do a google search there are plenty of sites dedicated to the Big Bang theory. Here are some that speak to the evidence that supports. You got something besides "I love Jesus and he says it ain't so so you are wrong" personally blathering?
 
 http://www.umich.edu/~gs265/bigbang.htm
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Bang
 http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/astronomy/bigbang.html
 
 Of course we can't know everything that happened before we were, but we can try and find out. Evidence can be studied and gathered, and in science a strict methodology is used. Just because it may not always match whatever scripture you adheare to does not mean that this evidence is weak or that scientists were lazy in their methodology. Nor does it mean they lacked faith. Personally what science discovers does an infinately better job of convincing me of an intelligent maker than any scripture or any dogma-clinging, gonna insult the scientific community when I can't even spell ridiculous correctly, religious nut will.

 Trust me, one day, the universe will be proven in a mathematical formula. IMO, it is a human "person" when it develops "person" characteristics. When its heart starts beating, when its brain develops, when it grows arms and legs. Im sorry, im not about to give a little ball of cells power over a woman's body.
 
 And no, its not an "attack on the human race". Pro-lifers devalue women to the point of having a ball of embryotic cells having control over their body. To me, pro-lifers attempt to devalue humans and the human race, therefore it is a very important issue.
 
 About you trying to prove that facts are "faith": if I could prove to you that the walls of your house are made of concrete, would you still call it a "faith statement"? No, its solid facts. Even if it is a theory, your God is still in hypothesis stage, with no evidence to back it up. Theory is in a much more advanced stage, therefore we should honor the theory and not the hypothesis, that is until that hypothesis can be proven. In the mean time, we should be open minded, not closed minded, conservative, and narrow. We should keep our minds open to all ideas.

 Those, i think, are the people with real brains. If they are christian, yet are able to keep their mind open to new ideas and new theorys. I congradulate those people. Unfortunately, the most christians arent like that. Most are closed minded and conservative.
 
 I still go to church, believe it or not. I go to a liberal Episcopal church. Even though i disagree with some of their preachings, i realize that these are some religious people with their heads on straight. I used to go to a conservative catholic church when i was little, but later I asked myself "What the heck am i doing here?!?!" and that was the end of that. I find my new church's teachings interesting, and i even enjoy going.
 
 That being said, i have much more respect for open minded christians or atheists than I do for Conservative, narrow minded christians.
